Found engineering drawings of Lindbergh's plane on internet. I wanted to build a snap together model that didn't require any glue.  All parts printed at once on a minimum 150 mm by 150 mm bed.

The Spirit of St. Louis is the custom-built, single engine, single-seat monoplane that was flown solo by Charles Lindbergh on May 20–21, 1927, on the first non-stop flight from New York to Paris for which Lindbergh won the $25,000 Orteig Prize.   
-Source: Wikipedia

Large end of propeller shaft goes in propeller.  
Print with no raft and no support material.

description.text: I find it annoying having to line up nuts under the bed when replacing bearing holders etc, so I designed these to make it easier.

Print 3x parts.  
The hexagons are undersized (6.8mm A/F). Squeeze the nuts into the part with a pair of pliers.  
Catch the first nut (the outside one) then swivel the part and catch the second one, and tighten. No spanner or pliers required. :)

description.text:
Here is an easy to mount Bowdenclamp, where you don't have to unassemble your complete Extrusionhead. Just take off the old plastic part and assemble this one. Simply add one of your spare m3 nuts and a 10mm bolt and there you go...  
Eine simple Bowdenklemme, bei der man nicht den ganzen Extruder auseinandernehmen muss. Einfach eine m3 Mutter und eine der 10mm Schrauben nehmen und der Schlauch sitzt fest.

description.text:
Have some paratroopers or items that you need to drop from the sky from your RC aircraft?  Then this is the module for you!
It is mounted to your aircraft using either double sided tape, velcro, or string.

You will need: RC airplane
Brave Paratrooper
Open channel on RX
Micro servo such as Hitec HS-55
Assortment of rubber bands.
Drill bit for drilling servo mounting holes.(usually 1/16")
Drill
Screwdriver
Velcro, double sided tape, or string.

description.text: This Deathly Hallows symbol makes a great necklace pendant and enchants any fan of Harry Potter. This is a fully assembled pendant with a rotating center. The top of the pendant features a 2mm hole for threading your favorite necklace or chain. This pendant measures at in: 1.972 w x 1.824 d x 0.197 h. Flick the circle in the center and watch it spin!

Pendant will print successfully on most FDM/FFF Printers. I printed the pedant on a Replicator 1 in Black ABS makerbot filament. This print works great with no raft but requires support and prints in about 10 minutes. The center circle has enough room to loosely rotate and spins freely. Careful removing the pendant from the build platform. Pendant was sliced using MakerWare with medium quality settings (makerslicer) Slice settings â€¢ 20% Infill
â€¢ 1 Shell
â€¢ 80/150 travel rates
â€¢ .20 mm layer height
â€¢ 240c/120c temp

It is just yet another shelf we designed - this time for an open space. It was designed by our OpenSCAD generator framework. Both the used Java source and the OpenSCAD result is there to download.
You can read - a little bit - more about the shelf on our page.

The ready stl files are for 6.6mm plexiglas - if you have different size you need to adjust it in the ClosedShelf.java with the PLEXI_THICK value.
After you've adjusted the thickness you have to print the two sides. Then cut two pieces of acrylic glass - one for the front and one for the bottom - put it together and drill it on the wall.
To make it easier to know what the result is the assembled version is also included as an OpenSCAD file.

description.text:
This is a short leg, to mount to the bottom rail of a Kossel Mini 3D printer.  
I've also included the design for a footpad, to be printed in NiniaFlex, or other flexible material.

I've made the .scad file parametric, in regards to length.  If you need longer legs, you can just change the parameter in the file, and regenerate the .stl.  
You can mount a leg at each end of each bottom rail, or one leg "bridging" each pair of bottom rails, at the corners.  
I wouldn't suggest mounting a single leg at the center of the bottom rails.  That would make your Kossel way too wobbly.   
The shafts on the footpads should hold them tight to the legs.  If you can't get the shaft all the way up inside the leg, you cut them off the pads, and try fixing the pads in place with hot glue.

title: ep82gt Toyota Starlet Glowing GT badge

description.text:
Hey Guys,  
Some of the series 1 ep82 Toyota Starlets had a glowing rear GT badge, over the years, the harsh sun takes it toll on the vinyl which makes up the GT lettering, degrading it and it looks like ass, for the most part. I thought to myself, why not clean up the area, remodel the GT bit, print it out and slap it into the housing?!  
I havent had a chance to print this yet, as i still dont have this particular garnish (my car has series 2, but ill be picking up an s1 piece shortly) and I am still working on refining the design, but all in all am pretty hopeful.  
When my motor blew last year i had some spare time on my hands, whilst waiting for my new motor and various parts, so i made my other GT themed design, a GT centre cap for my wheel, check it out via my profile, for you other starlet owners and lovers!  
Sketchup file is provided for those wishing to refine the design further!!
modelled off a picture in sketchup, still refining the design though

description.text: The Key to Erebor. Lord of the rings replica.

This key will need to be built using support. The square at the end of
the key, is not touching any sides, and will move freely once the
support has been removed. I did not add any of the graphics to the key,
so its just a plain Key to Erebor.

I like to keep my Wacom on my desk, but laying flat it takes up desk space.  I prop it on its side but it falls over occasionally, or I bump the pen holder.  
I put this together using openScad and I'm pretty happy with the results. I'll probably add some balance support to the side opposite the pen holder. For now though, it's working well for me.

I printed this using Makerware default medium settings on a Rep2.  The included openScad file contains some basic comments.   
I think this should work for different size tablets, I think the pen holder size and tablet thickness are probably uniform across different models.  
Feel free to ask any questions.

description.text: [Entry under construction] This is a piece of urban furniture, developed through a process of collaborative design using digital design and digital fabrication tools. The piece works as an urban bench. It can be used as well as a small stage. It is built in 12 mm plywood, using a simple contour/section technique. Dimensions: 2418 mm x 3180 mm x 642 mm It is in the way of being parametrized [with Grasshopper] so that it can be adapted to different situations and sites. The design was developed within the Fabbing CC project, that took place in Caceres [Spain]. As it is one of our first tries with these object size the piece has to be considered a beta version. Improvements to be made include [1] the redesign of joints to make the press fit process smoother and more comfortable and [2] to include some kind of pieces in the joints that keep the sections in their position once they are there, and [3] a better design of the contact between the piece and the ground, that allows [a] for an easier assemblage process, [b] for easy adjustment to uneven ground, and [c] for protection from ground humidity affecting the plywood; [4] general dimensions can be improved too in order to have a more efficient use of the size of plywood sheets [especially concerning horizontal pieces. These piece was designed for a specific site and position that conditioned our dimensions, which were not very efficient. Design, fabrication and assemblage team: The Sevilla Fablab team 2011, Jose Buzon, Carla Boserman, Adolfo ChautÃ³n, Jaime Diez, Manuel Gutierrez de Rueda, Juanjo Olmo, Jose Perez de Lama, Juan Carlos PÃ©rez Juidias, Juanjo Pulido, Jose M. Sanchez Laulhe, Juan Carlos Venegas, Sabah Walid. More info about the collaborative design process and other pieces designed: http://htca.us.es/blogs/fabbingcc [Spanish]

Rhinoceros file corresponds to version 4.0 SR8.
Assemblage with these cutting files is rather difficult because of the high friction with the long joints. A very flat base is strongly recommended. Plywood sheets should be as flat as possible.
As a guide for assemblage main sections in both directions are separated 360 mm from one another. In the transversal dimensions secondary sections are separated 180 mm from each other.
Nesting can also be improved. With these sizes it should be possible to use 15 2400 x 1200 sheets instead of the 17 in the cutting file attached.
The images describe the recommended assemblage process.
In a next version we will incorporate the suggested improvements.

remixed_from.author: falcon20cne
remixed_from.title: DJI Phantom 2 Vision + Camera Gimbal lock lens cover

title: DJI Phantom 3 Camera Gimbal & Cover protector ...

description.text: This Gimbal protector replaces the fidly default piece of plastic that takes to much time to mount. The entire thing prints in one go without supports (genius idea by Falcon20 to rotate it 45°). The lock hinge has a fine support that breaks away to make the hinge rotate freely. Here you can see me breaking away the hinge support & protecting to my Phantom gimbal : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_6wNicOl17o I have only tested it on the DJI Phantom 3 Professional but I believe the camera size is the same. If anyone could confirm this it would be appreciated. All comments, remarks & suggestions are welcome. [edit] I have added (but not printed yet) a version with a fat base as someone had problems printing the smaller one. I've also cut off just the base in case you want to try the base & hinge first). Here's a review of the item : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fZ6oX5jBLtk

I've also added just the hinge so you can see if it prints and works fine on your printer before printing the whole thing (which can take quite some time). It's the file called :
DJiPhantomThreeCameraGimbalLockFatBaseOnly.stl

comments.text: Thanks for a great DJI Phantom 3 Accessory.  This is much better than the standard DJI Gimbal Lock.  Its easier to install and remove, and it protects the Gimbal and Camera far better.  I printed two copies (one Red and one White) and both printed very nicely in PLA on my MakerBot 5th Generation Printer.  My print settings were: Quality=Standard; Layers=0.15mm; Infill=20%; Shells=4; Raft=Yes; Supports=No.  Final finishing was very minor and only consisted of cleaning up a couple of downside edges slightly - 5 minutes max.  This is a great example of the wonderful/useful things that can be made via 3D Printing.  One small suggestion: I think it would require virtually no final finishing at all if you could add a small (1-2mm) radius along the Downside edges (as printed) of the large rectangular strut between the Lens Cover and the Leg Clamp.  -mike-

title: Toyota Starlet Ep82GT GT centre cap

Hey guys,  
When my motor blew last year i had some spare time on my hands, whilst waiting for my new motor and various parts, I made GT  centre caps for my wheels!  
I had alot of fun with this, had a mate saying it would just melt, but he has no idea on 3d printing, or materials, and its been 9months now...still going strong...PLA has held up against the heat, brake dust and the elements, they still look great.

description.text:
I didn't want to solder the wires to my heated build platform.  I was also afraid that using 3 pin and 2 pin headers would, they would come apart or get damaged while printing.  It's also hard to grab those little suckers in the back of your bot.
This connector slides over the wires and a full length 10 pin female header and holds everthing in place tightly.  I put a little hot glue on the wires, but it really wasn't necessary.  This not only provides support and strain relief for the solder connection, but also provides a good surface for your fingers to purchase on for taking the connector on and off when you need to access the HBP - like when you want to remove or apply painters tape.

Buy or cut a 10 pin female header.
Solder the thermistor and power connections.
Print the connector sleeve.
Slide the wires through the connector sleeve.
Glue if you wish.

remixed_from.author: GeoDave
remixed_from.title: X-idler Mount Plate and related parts for Makerfarm i3v 10"

title: X-idler Mount Plate with X-axis belt tensioning for Makerfarm i3v 10"

description.text: After putting my original design of this on my printer, I realized I could add a belt tensioning adjustment by changing the hole that the idler screw goes thru to be open on that end thus being able to slide the idler pulley along the x-axis to tension or lossen the belt. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:866648 for more info about the original design. This will probably work for the 8" & 12" version. The eccentric spacer holes are countersunk, so you do not need a washer where the lock nut attaches. I personally put a washer between the locknut & the plastic. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795954 for the connection to the Z-axis threaded rod instead of the original wooden part. If you use the wooden part, you will most likely need to do some filing on the rectangle hole. I also noticed it was a rather tight fit with that wooden part next to the Top wheel nut.

Print the following or edit the openscad files:
either i3v_X-IdlerMount_3Wheel_WithEars_rev11_repaired.stl
or i3v_X-IdlerMount_3Wheel_NoEars_rev11_repaired.stl X-IdlerPulleyParts_rev5_repaired.stl (replaces wooden idler parts & can tension or lossen belt)
ZLimitScrewPlate_rev3_repaired.stl (replaces wooden Z-limit screw plate) I added a couple of cones to the X-IdlerPulleyParts file to allow the plastic to cool on the dovetail joint, so it would be a smoother joint. You can edit the openscad file if you do not need that. See photo of how to assemble the 2 parts for the idler pulley Remove any of the extra plastic from the wheel holes by hand turning a 5/16" bit for the eccentric countersunk holes
& 3/16" bit for the M5 bolts that go on the wheels. I would also print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795954 that connects to the Z-axis threaded rod instead of using the stock wooden part. I am not sure how well that original wooden part will fit with this plastic version. Build thread for this design: http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?13185-Plastic-X-Idler-Plate-to-replace-Wood-Parts

description.text: Customized version of WarFairy's Minimalist Stock, enhanced with a flexible cushion grip. Attaches to milspec buffer tubes by way of a .3" roll pin. The perfect compliment to a 7.5" or 10.5" upper.

Printed the stock itself using ABS Polycarbonate, 100% fill. I experienced some lifting on my first three attempts, finally found a fix by applying blue tape to the bed and brushing on a light film of acetone ABS slurry. Issues are probably related to me and my novice-ness.  
Butt Pad (haha) was printed using flex TPC polyester. Had to slow the speed way down, like 60%. I went with 20% fill, but if I was doing it again I would go 10-15% to enhance the cushion aspect.   
Don't mind my glue issues, I'm sure you'll do much better.

author: ajlynch

description.text: This is a ring for a baby wearing type of ring sling, nothing fancy.
0% infill 3 shells

Two little tools to see if your Ultimaker XY guiding rods timing belts are correctly aligned according to the 'sliding blocks'
The optimum is that the timing belt of the X -rod has no Y component, so the 2 pullies and the 'sliding block' must be in the same Y-plane.
This should reduce mechanical stress in the system and gives a more balanced load for the belts/pulleys.
It can be difficult to see if the pulley is mounted straight above/below the rods. The tool has a complexity/added value ratio of 1 (It can boost your Ultimaker performance with at least 0.000005%)

Place the rounded tool over the X rod and see if the underlying belt is not touching the legs (4 times, each corner once).
Place the right-angled tool over the Y belts and see if the underlying rod is not touching the legs (4 times)

comments.text: Two questions, if these are printed on a machine that might not be perfectly aligned, will they still be helpful? I used a spare block of wood and moved the head all the way one direction, measured one block length between that and the pully, then moved it all the way to the other and measured the same.
comments.author: Mazaw

comments.text:
I know its very late for a response, but this model helps diagnose the phantom "clicking" that one might hear while operating an Ultimaker.
Calibrating the position of the Gear Pulleys will quieten the machine and increase overall longevity, i found out the hard way after ignoring the clicking that it eventually destroyed the timing belt.
comments.author: Mazaw

comments.text: Every 0.000005% counts!! You know that with 8 pulleys it really starts to add up (a whopping 0.00004%!!)  8-)

description.text:
Remixed the photo frame to integrate it with backlit LED(s);  
Depending on how you want it back-lit, you can use a single LED (center) or two (left/right).   It should all friction fit although PLA required some sanding. Prints without support. You can glue the LED bridge to the frame if needed to keep the arms from expanding out.  
To use two LEDs:  
Option 1 - put the two LEDs on the LED bridge, to the left and right of the battery making sure your polarity is correct and insert cap apply enough pressure turn it on.  
Option 2 - insert LEDs into side bar then interweave into CR2025/CR2032 battery and insert cap to turn it on.  This way you could slide the LED bridge out to turn it off or swap out LEDs colors a little easier.  
The LED leads I use are long enough so I don't need to solder any wires unless you put the LEDs on the furthest part of the side bar. Single battery should last up to 2-3 weeks - orange and red LEDs should use a resistor; this is intended for an always on gallery/showcase installation - designing a real switch element would be ideal however that would probably require you to do some soldering and/or some redesign of the base/cap to avoid soldering although could include a mini-breadboard on the back side if it didn't weigh it all down too much...

title: KP001 Pillow Block Bearing for 12mm Shaft

description.text: I found the FK KP001 to be a handy part to have in designing a 3D printer mechanism, so I made a CAD file of it. Available as STL for 3D previews here, in AD_PRT (Geomagic Design) and STEP. It's a pillow block with a bearing inside, and what makes it interesting to me is that it includes two set screws to hold the shaft, and that it's inexpensive and pretty convenient to use. It saves me having to build a bunch of pillow blocks and use shaft collars. It's meant to be a mechanical stand-in for designing a machine, the mount faces, hole locations, hole sizes, offsets, relative positions and bores are reasonably accurate. I did work it into a reasonably faithful looking model, though it's not a perfectly faithful in a few places that don't matter for making a mechanical design. These (or most likely, clones of these) are available cheaply on Aliexpress (Alibaba), eBay and Amazon. See http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:728234 for KP000, the 10mm version.

author: anstett

description.text:
Create a windmill using 3 water bottle. This windmill base has 3 screw in sockets to put common water bottle in. Screw in the bottle, see which direction it ends up in and cut the bottle to create a wing.
Designed for a 4mm steel rod. The windmill seems to pick up a small breeze but for now it quickly stops, due to too much friction. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=giOfWCM8xGs&feature=youtu.be

• Get 3 plastic bottles
  • Screw them on first to see in which position they will end
  • Cut half of the bottle to create a wing
  • Screw them back on

comments.text: I do believe that your design would benefit from a bearing or two, and perhaps a printable guide (two if you use regular small bottles and larger two liter bottles) so we know how best to cut the bottle to maximize power. And have you attempted this design with four bottles instead of three? i Don't know if that would make a positive difference, but it might. Also, what material did you print this out of? i assume abs?

This is a helical version of Ed Lenz' Lenz2 turbine blade. His homepage is here http://www.windstuffnow.com/main/lenz2_turbine.htm Dimensions: this should give a 120mm diameter, 160mm height windmill. 2013-06-09: Hey look, I made a larger one - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99132 31-5-2013: I managed to print the last layer last week and the turbine is now spinning in the wind. I started thinking about making a larger version of this that i can still print on the 200mm print bed.
The larger version that i am working on is going to be mounted on a electric bicycle brushless 3 phase hub motor of about 200 Watts. It will also use aluminium arms (20Ã—2mm flat) instead of the plastic ones.
The new thing id will follow later. 18-05-2013: Crud, broke the pulley on my 3D printer, posted the picture of it on a wooden stick on the back of my shed. It only has 2 layers now, 3rd one later when I fix the printer. 18-05-2013: Just uploaded a double bearing holder so I can mount it on a 44x44mm wooden pole. The bearings I am using have a 32mm outer diameter. They are not really the correct size for a 12cm diameter windmill. I'm planning a larger one for later. The bearing holder doesn't print very well, word of caution. I've also reuploaded the single blades for 30 and 40 degrees which now have a 1 degree resolution. Same thing, looks nicer, takes longer to slice. Also turns out you can print 3 single blades and a hub on a single 20x20 bed. When printing on scale 1:1 you can apparently print these without support which makes them look a lot prettier. Printing a single blade at 0.3mm height takes about 1 hour 45 minutes here. Printing 3 at once with hub is about 4 hours. Seems like a good deal. 16-05-2013: Uploaded a hex center hub to mount the single blades on. I'll probably add a hex nut cage on it for easier assembly. Perhaps nut cages on the blade mounting hole would make sense too. 15-05-2013: I just uploaded a new single blade with mounting hole which can be mounted on a central. That way you can mount 3 of these for a single 1/3 rotation (40 degrees of 120) 53,3mm high helical form. This allows for making a larger version(s) with the limitation that 3D printers have in build volume. With repetier host you can easily scale a single blade by a factor of 3 to get a 160mm high single blade. That would result in a 480mm high windmill! Still working on the central hub, still evaluating CAD programs to do my bidding. 14-05-2013: I'll be adding seperate blades with different heights and a hub carrier so it's easier to print larger versions with the restricted print bed size. Should have this done this week. I don't recommend printing the entire helix with supports, as these will overlap with the next blade. (That won't be a issue with seperate blades) The model is a bit too complicated for Sketchup, which it also imports every dimension multiplied by 25,4. That means it is doing the unit conversion wrong. That is a issue with the STL importer for Sketchup. These STL files are hole free and should go through Slic3r without warnings.
Single Blade

If you print the single blade you need 3 blades to make a single level. I've only left the 53,3mm 40 degree turn blade for now.  
You need to mount these on a central hub with a M3 screw+nut. The central hub is not here yet. That is forthcoming.  
Layer assembly

You can use super glue to glue the layers together.  
I've added the entire helix as well so people can modify it to print 1/2 height 60 degrees rotation too. The lower height model slices well as it is far less complicated over the entire helix. It also allows for easier printing.

comments.text: im printing a pink (blush) version of your 30deg variety in 150% around 20cm in height (3layers). Im into the 3rd layer now and I wanted to ask one thing. do the nuts that hold the main pole and the layers together need to be selflocking nuts? Im afraid that as the windmill wil turn the nuts that fasten the windmil to the pole will unscrew itself

This GPS mount is only for the KTM 990 SM-T and allows to mount the GPS unit (ZUMO 210 in my case) just under the windshield. Requires some work and drilling on the bike, but the result is GPS unit in direct front sight and clearly visible RPM gauge.

Print each part from the set and prepare/buy the following stuff:
1x screw M6 x 50 with hexagonal head + 1x M6 Nut.
3x Inbus screw M5 x 50 + 3x M5 Nut + 6x M5 washer.
4x 20 mm rubber (foam) rings with 5 mm holes
3x Inbus screw M5 x 20, 1x Inbus screw M5 x 30 + 4x M5 Nut + 8x M5 washer. After printing the parts join the L/C/R parts with M5x50 screws. Insert the M6x60 throught the knob and fix the GPS mount part between the left and right arm.
"Undress" the bike :) - unscrew both front side panels and dismount the front cover. Clean the surface and draw axis line, following the front widshield mount (see the picture). Find the right place for the mount and drill 5.5 mm holes (28 mm to the left and right). Note that the whole mount must sit on rubber rings behind the dashboard. Don't overtight screws. The top-left screw on the picture is the longer one (M5 x 30) due to the asymetry of the plastic cover.
That's all, finish the wiring and dress the bike up again . And my last notice: I took switched 12V from parking light, there are 2 wires behind the light, brown is the ground and the yellow one is 12V.

I needed a cam lock device to assist tying my canoe up to the river bank nice and tight so that it wont move when I get out and in. The rope is connected to one end of the canoe the other end of the canoe has the rope slide through a carabiner. After the rope/cord is thrown over a bollard or similar the loose end is located as shown in the photos and pulled tight.

author: DallasNYC

description.text:
Having found nothing that fits a 15mm square boom - linkage free - , I designed one. Here it is.
  • Protects motor shaft and bearing
  • Full 180 degres range, servo is never going to bind
  • The screw can't fall out
  • Enough space on the side to ziptie the esc.
  • Grip for the zipties that hold the servo
    • Solidworks files included.
• 07/23/2015 - The motor mount now has a lower profile. That was a weakpoint.

• M3 screw and nut for tilt, locknut preferred
  • 2x M3 screw and nut to attach the base to the arm.
  • A big servo arm, with one side removed
  • Cutter and grease to smooth things out.
  • Drillbit to cleanup holes.
    • Printed fast (75mm/s) in ABS, 0.2mm layer height.

• Print without support. As they are.
  • Drill out the M3 holes for the tilt itself
  • Smooth out the 2 parts so they just fit (Important, otherwise you will have a a lot of slop on your tilt.)
  • Add the M3 screw, as shown on the picture.
  • Add the servo with the arm, You should secure it with a little bit of CA glue on the bottom. If the servo arm don't fit, use a 2mm drillbit.
    The servo arm should be able to move a little, otherwise the servo will be stressed
  • Ziptie the servo.
  • Fly
the sing for the friendship between you and your buddy
Just adjust size as you want it with a programm like MeshLab or else

description.text:
This 3D print is the end cap of a Chop Saw or Miter Saw hold down stick. When the wood is small, this tool holds down the wood without your fingers being too close to the blade. Here is my YouTube Video on this project:
https://youtu.be/RikvNH-HgLM
I used Tinkercad to create the end cap and then a 1" dowel rod for the handle.

title: badBrick - Mount Brick for 10K023-530 Potentiometer POT

description.text:
Fits 1 (one)  10K Ohm Potentiometer in a compatible mount Brick.  This mount brick is specifically intended for a 10K023-530 Potentiometer (POT)  
The Brick itself can be stand alone or mounted. This Brick is probably compatible with other generic 10K Ohm Potentiometer considering they have similar dimensions. We optimized it for the 10K023-530 Potentiometer (POT) because we use them in our kits.  
If you don't have a 3D printer but you're interested in getting one of these we can print you one at badbrick.com/catalog

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings: For the Brick and the knob:
Quality: Layer Height = 0.2 and I increase the temp to 240C to let the little larger prints fuse better.

title: Rod adapter for Xnaron Printable Magnetic u-joint for Rostocks

description.text:
• Updated to add a 4mm rod version.
    • This is an adapter I made so I can use some carbon fiber rods I already had and that are readily available from Hobbytownusa locally. The original files were for 3/8" rods. Mine are about 5.5mm / .188" OD from http://www.hobbytown.com/Shop/Carbon-Fiber-Tube-24-188-OD/

Print 12 of these and then insert the rods and glue everything in place. Once these are on the rod ends they can then be inserted into the main coupler that holds the magnet. I am including a link to the original files (not including them here). Main files and instructions:
http://forum.seemecnc.com/viewtopic.php?f=54&t=1704&p=10703#p10703
https://github.com/xnaron/Xnaron-Magnarms-for-Rostock

author: jamesarm97

description.text:
Set of 12 Pentominoes with 2cm edges and 2cm height.  All surfaces have been pulled back 200 microns so that points would fit into the gap in the "U", etc.  These came out extremely well in Transparent Orange PLA on my Wanhao Duplicator 4X. Read instructions regarding shell count for the box.  
Arrange them 10x6, 12x5 etc. ... or 5x4x3 to fit neatly into the box.

Just print 'em ... 200 micron layer height, 2 shells, 15% fill-in worked very well on my printer.  
IMPORTANT: Print the box with SINGLE shell and 30% fill-in.

title: case designed for the Papilio Pro FPGA development board

description.text: top and bottom case parts for a Papilio Pro( http://store.gadgetfactory.net/papilio-pro/ ) FPGA board which when combined with a logic analyzer firmware upload turns the board into a 200MHz 16bit logic analyzer. With an added 16bit I/O level shifter "Wing" it can handle 0-7v logic( as opposed to 0-3.3V logic).

Print one top and one bottom .2mm layer 2 or more perimeters and 20% or more infill should work fine.  
The bottom corners have detents for M3 nuts but an M3x12 alone will hold the lid on while not entering the detent. An M3x15 would probably work with the nuts but if an M3x16 is used then a washer or 2 or 3 should be used on the lid side otherwise the threads will stick out. Maybe hot glue on the threads would work as a protector and as anti-skid.

title: Bukito 20mm  PLA Cooling Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an alternative cooling fan duct design to the Bukito version released by Deezmaker:
http://www.bukobot.com/bukito-pla-cooling-fan-duct I used the Deezemaker version for a while but found that I occasionally had some issues of the fan duct hitting the screws on the print bed if the print job extended towards the Left side (fan side). As well, I could only see the nozzle from the right side when adjusting the bed height. I made this new version to put it towards the front of the machine print head where the original OEM plexiglass fan kit was mounted rather than to the side.

Make sure you mount the fan in the correct orientation and not upside down. I've included support material under the bracket. Just break off after printing. You should have extra screws to mount the fan.
